body.value: In the imperial era, particularly before the 1857 Sepoy Uprising in which Indian soldiers throughout the Indian subcontinent rebelled against British imperialists, many Britons in India (often called Anglo-Indians) partook in a number of South Asian practices, from consumption habits to leisure activities. British popular discourse revolved around anxieties that these Anglo-Indians were "going native."

In this lithograph, the artist explores cultural anxieties about Indian influences on Anglo-Indians through his depiction of the young woman, the servants catering to her, and the objects shown in the background and foreground.
We see a parrot in the background sitting in front of a lacquer screen from China, which scholars have argued might be a reference to Indian Ocean trade routes.
